issue.title: vip_cidr ignored, always 32
issue.body:
kube-vip v0.4.0

```yaml
containers:
        - name: kube-vip
          image: 'ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.4.0'
          args:
            - manager
          env:
            - name: vip_arp
              value: 'true'
            - name: port
              value: '6443'
            - name: vip_interface
              value: enp35s0.4000
            - name: vip_cidr
              value: '29'
            - name: svc_enable
              value: 'true'
```

```
kubectl describe configmap -n kube-system kubevip
Name:         kubevip
Namespace:    kube-system
Labels:       <none>
Annotations:  <none>

Data
====
range-global:
----
321.321.321.218-321.321.321.222
Events:  <none>
```

```
ip addr show enp35s0.4000
3: enp35s0.4000@enp35s0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1400 qdisc noqueue state UP
    inet 321.321.321.221/32 scope global enp35s0.4000
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
```

Can anyone tell me what to do to have `/29` assigned?
Thx.

pull_request.title: Update home page
pull_request.body:
## Description

Update the landing page's services to be representative of our current direction/service set. This includes:

- stop mentioning OSIE.
- add a note about `tink-controller`.
- add Rufio.
- stop mentioning Postgres.
- redirect new starts to the sandbox repository.

With respect to removing Postgres docs, I was split. We haven't implemented this yet but we have agreed its the direction we're taking. The Sandbox does still reference it and I felt that's OK until we get the sandbox functional with the Kubernetes back-end and begin stripping Postgres out. Updating this to no longer mention Postgres is going to steer people towrad Kubernetes.

issue.title: [0.5.0] externalTrafficPolicy: Local does not work. kube-vip does not detect endpoint changes in table mode (or at all?)
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
externalTrafficPolicy: Local does not work. kube-vip does not detect endpoint changes in table mode (or at all?)

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1.Apply service + single-pod deployment manifest with affinity to single node (i.e. test-lab-worker02 in my case)
2. Change deployment pod affinity to another node (i.e. test-lab-worker03 in my case)
3. See no changes for loadbalancer address announcement

**Expected behavior**
kube-vip must remove the loadbalancer ip address announcement  from the node with no local pods and add it to another node

**Screenshots**
Deployment manifest
```
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: nginx
  labels:
    app: nginx
spec:
  ports:
  - port: 80
    protocol: TCP
    name: http
  selector:
    app: nginx
  externalTrafficPolicy: Local
  type: LoadBalancer
  loadBalancerIP: 192.168.164.64
---
kind: Deployment
apiVersion: apps/v1
metadata:
  name: nginx
  labels:
    app: nginx
spec:
  replicas: 1
  strategy:
    type: RollingUpdate
    rollingUpdate:
      maxSurge: 0
      maxUnavailable: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: nginx
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: nginx
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: kubernetes.io/hostname
                operator: In
                values:
                - test-lab-worker02
      containers:
      - image: nginx:1.21.5
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        name: nginx
        ports:
        - containerPort: 80
          protocol: TCP
```

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Ubuntu 1804
 - Kubernetes Version: v.1.20.15
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.0

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: ServiceAccount
metadata:
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
---
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
kind: ClusterRole
metadata:
  annotations:
    rbac.authorization.kubernetes.io/autoupdate: "true"
  name: system:kube-vip-role
rules:
  - apiGroups: [""]
    resources: ["services", "services/status", "nodes", "endpoints"]
    verbs: ["list","get","watch", "update"]
  - apiGroups: ["coordination.k8s.io"]
    resources: ["leases"]
    verbs: ["list", "get", "watch", "update", "create"]
---
kind: ClusterRoleBinding
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: system:kube-vip-binding
roleRef:
  apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
  kind: ClusterRole
  name: system:kube-vip-role
subjects:
- kind: ServiceAccount
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
---

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
    app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
        app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
    spec:
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        - --log=5
        - --table
        - --services
        - --servicesElection
        - --serviceInterface=kube-dummy-if
        image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.0
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
      hostNetwork: true
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
```

**Additional context**
kube-vip logs (initial pod placenent node)
```
time="2022-09-09T12:30:33Z" level=info msg="Starting kube-vip.io [v0.5.0]"
time="2022-09-09T12:30:33Z" level=info msg="namespace [kube-system], Mode: [Routing Table], Features(s): Control Plane:[false], Services:[true]"

issue.title: Question: multiple pods on different node - using the same egress IP?
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Is it possible to configure egress in a way that a deployment having multiple PODs on different nodes using the same egress VIP for outgoing traffic?

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Cluster with 10 nodes where three have a secondary NIC for egress traffic.
Configure kube-vip with a single VIP to be running on the three egress nodes.
Deploy a deployment with 10 pods - one on each node.
Configure kube-vip for this deployment to do egress over a single VIP.

**Expected behavior**
If a POD is hosted on node1 and egress VIP is on node 4 (secondary 5,6) - the egress traffic POD on node1 should go out via node 4 with the VIP specified in kube-vip.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: CentOS 7.9
 - Kubernetes Version: 1.22
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.5

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  annotations:
    deprecated.daemonset.template.generation: "4"
    meta.helm.sh/release-name: kube-vip
    meta.helm.sh/release-namespace: kube-vip
  creationTimestamp: "2022-10-12T14:28:41Z"
  generation: 4
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/managed-by: Helm
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-vip
  resourceVersion: "29852231"
  uid: ab939ff7-7cf5-4742-9d70-d939d84b6b34
spec:
  revisionHistoryLimit: 10
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/instance: kube-vip
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/instance: kube-vip
        app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: is_edge
                operator: In
                values:
                - "true"
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: vip_address
          value: 10.141.48.13
        - name: cp_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: lb_enable
          value: "false"
        - name: lb_port
          value: "6443"
        - name: svc_election
          value: "true"
        - name: svc_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_arp
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_cidr
          value: "32"
        - name: vip_interface
          value: eth1
        - name: vip_leaderelection
          value: "false"
        image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip-iptables:v0.5.5
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
        terminationMessagePath: /dev/termination-log
        terminationMessagePolicy: File
      dnsPolicy: ClusterFirst
      hostNetwork: true
      restartPolicy: Always
      schedulerName: default-scheduler
      securityContext: {}
      serviceAccount: kube-vip
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
      terminationGracePeriodSeconds: 30
      tolerations:
      - effect: NoSchedule
        key: node-role.kubernetes.io/control-plane
        operator: Exists
  updateStrategy:
    rollingUpdate:
      maxSurge: 0
      maxUnavailable: 1
    type: RollingUpdate

```

comment.body:
So technically it might be possible in the future however that would probably require routing traffic from a pod to an egress gateway, meaning it doesn't matter where the pod is currently running traffic is always sent to "somewhere", where it is then modified and sent on to it's final destination.

Today the re-write is done in-kernel and therefore everything has to happen on the node where a chosen pod is running. So that's why service election is required and external policy local.

issue.title: [0.5.0] externalTrafficPolicy: Local does not work. kube-vip does not detect endpoint changes in table mode (or at all?)
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
externalTrafficPolicy: Local does not work. kube-vip does not detect endpoint changes in table mode (or at all?)

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1.Apply service + single-pod deployment manifest with affinity to single node (i.e. test-lab-worker02 in my case)
2. Change deployment pod affinity to another node (i.e. test-lab-worker03 in my case)
3. See no changes for loadbalancer address announcement

**Expected behavior**
kube-vip must remove the loadbalancer ip address announcement  from the node with no local pods and add it to another node

**Screenshots**
Deployment manifest
```
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: nginx
  labels:
    app: nginx
spec:
  ports:
  - port: 80
    protocol: TCP
    name: http
  selector:
    app: nginx
  externalTrafficPolicy: Local
  type: LoadBalancer
  loadBalancerIP: 192.168.164.64
---
kind: Deployment
apiVersion: apps/v1
metadata:
  name: nginx
  labels:
    app: nginx
spec:
  replicas: 1
  strategy:
    type: RollingUpdate
    rollingUpdate:
      maxSurge: 0
      maxUnavailable: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: nginx
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: nginx
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: kubernetes.io/hostname
                operator: In
                values:
                - test-lab-worker02
      containers:
      - image: nginx:1.21.5
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        name: nginx
        ports:
        - containerPort: 80
          protocol: TCP
```

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Ubuntu 1804
 - Kubernetes Version: v.1.20.15
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.0

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: ServiceAccount
metadata:
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
---
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
kind: ClusterRole
metadata:
  annotations:
    rbac.authorization.kubernetes.io/autoupdate: "true"
  name: system:kube-vip-role
rules:
  - apiGroups: [""]
    resources: ["services", "services/status", "nodes", "endpoints"]
    verbs: ["list","get","watch", "update"]
  - apiGroups: ["coordination.k8s.io"]
    resources: ["leases"]
    verbs: ["list", "get", "watch", "update", "create"]
---
kind: ClusterRoleBinding
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: system:kube-vip-binding
roleRef:
  apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
  kind: ClusterRole
  name: system:kube-vip-role
subjects:
- kind: ServiceAccount
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
---

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
    app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
        app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
    spec:
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        - --log=5
        - --table
        - --services
        - --servicesElection
        - --serviceInterface=kube-dummy-if
        image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.0
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
      hostNetwork: true
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
```

**Additional context**
kube-vip logs (initial pod placenent node)
```
time="2022-09-09T12:30:33Z" level=info msg="Starting kube-vip.io [v0.5.0]"
time="2022-09-09T12:30:33Z" level=info msg="namespace [kube-system], Mode: [Routing Table], Features(s): Control Plane:[false], Services:[true]"
time="2022-09-09T12:30:33Z" level=info msg="No interface is specified for VIP in config, auto-detecting default Interface"
time="2022-09-09T12:30:33Z" level=info msg="kube-vip will bind to interface [ens3]"

time="2022-09-09T12:35:02Z" level=info msg="beginning services leadership, namespace [default], lock name [kubevip-nginx], id [adm-vm-k8s-test-lab-worker02]"
I0909 12:35:02.601865       1 leaderelection.go:248] attempting to acquire leader lease default/kubevip-nginx...

```
kube-vip logs (second node)
```

time="2022-09-09T12:30:35Z" level=info msg="namespace [kube-system], Mode: [Routing Table], Features(s): Control Plane:[false], Services:[true]"
time="2022-09-09T12:30:35Z" level=info msg="No interface is specified for VIP in config, auto-detecting default Interface"
time="2022-09-09T12:30:35Z" level=info msg="prometheus HTTP server started"

time="2022-09-09T12:30:35Z" level=info msg="all routing table entries will exist in table [198]"
time="2022-09-09T12:30:35Z" level=info msg="beginning watching services, leaderelection will happen for every service"
time="2022-09-09T12:30:35Z" level=warning msg="loadBalancer has External Traffic Policy: Local, no local pods found"
time="2022-09-09T12:35:04Z" level=warning msg="loadBalancer has External Traffic Policy: Local, no local pods found"
<< nothing about endpoint change here >>

```

It seems this issue is related to #431

comment.body: With the latest release 5.5 there now is a endpoint watcher that will continually watch for pod endpoints and adjust when things become available or things such as pods/nodes are removed.

issue.title: externalTrafficPolicy Local not working as expected
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Creating a service with `externalTrafficPolicy: Local` never gets advertised by kube-vip after receiving a loadbalancerIP from kube-vip-cloud-provider.

Logs complain that no local pods were found, even though they exist.

If I create the service with `externalTrafficPolicy: Cluster` it gets an IP, and if I edit/update the service and set `externalTrafficPolicy: Local` I get Local behavior as expected.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Deploy kube-vip + kube-vip-cloud-provider
  - ARP mode, see manifest below
2. Configure cidr/range for kvcp
3. Deploy a service with `externalTrafficPolicy: Local`
4. ExternalIP stuck in pending

**Expected behavior**
I expected kube-vip to advertise the IP.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Ubuntu 22.04
 - Kubernetes Version: k3s 1.23.9
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.0

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```yaml
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  revisionHistoryLimit: 10
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        name: kube-vip-ds
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/control-plane
                operator: Exists
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: cp_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: svc_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: address
          value: 192.168.60.100
        - name: port
          value: "6443"
        - name: vip_ddns
          value: "false"
        - name: prometheus_server
          value: :2112
        - name: vip_arp
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_interface
          value: eth0
        - name: vip_leaderelection
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_leaseduration
          value: "5"
        - name: vip_renewdeadline
          value: "3"
        - name: vip_retryperiod
          value: "1"
        - name: svc_election
          value: "true"
        image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.0
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
      dnsPolicy: ClusterFirst
      hostNetwork: true
      restartPolicy: Always
      schedulerName: default-scheduler
      securityContext: {}
      serviceAccount: kube-vip
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
      terminationGracePeriodSeconds: 30
      tolerations:
      - effect: NoSchedule
        operator: Exists
      - effect: NoExecute
        operator: Exists
  updateStrategy:
    rollingUpdate:
      maxSurge: 0
      maxUnavailable: 1
    type: RollingUpdate
status:
  currentNumberScheduled: 3
  desiredNumberScheduled: 3
  numberAvailable: 3
  numberMisscheduled: 0
  numberReady: 3
  observedGeneration: 2
  updatedNumberScheduled: 3
```

**Additional context**

Output from `kubectl get pod,svc -A -owide`:
```
NAMESPACE     NAME                            READY   STATUS    RESTARTS        AGE    IP                NODE    NOMINATED NODE   READINESS GATES
default       pod/whoami-76b79cb87f-dbprt     1/1     Running   0               15m    10.42.1.15        kube2   <none>           <none>
default       pod/whoami-76b79cb87f-fzkxq     1/1     Running   0               15m    10.42.0.16        kube1   <none>           <none>
default       pod/whoami-76b79cb87f-gknw2     1/1     Running   0               15m    10.42.2.15        kube3   <none>           <none>
kube-system   pod/kube-vip-cloud-provider-0   1/1     Running   0               130m   10.42.2.4         kube3   <none>           <none>
kube-system   pod/kube-vip-ds-gcnhc           1/1     Running   1 (4h3m ago)    4h7m   192.168.121.205   kube3   <none>           <none>
kube-system   pod/kube-vip-ds-l6kmg           1/1     Running   1 (3h59m ago)   4h7m   192.168.121.107   kube1   <none>           <none>
kube-system   pod/kube-vip-ds-p4cgh           1/1     Running   1 (4h3m ago)    4h7m   192.168.121.135   kube2   <none>           <none>

NAMESPACE     NAME                      TYPE           CLUSTER-IP      EXTERNAL-IP     PORT(S)                  AGE    SELECTOR
default       service/kubernetes        ClusterIP      10.43.0.1       <none>          443/TCP                  4h8m   <none>
default       service/whoami-service    LoadBalancer   10.43.81.93     <pending>       80:31588/TCP             15m    app=whoami
kube-system   service/kube-dns          ClusterIP      10.43.0.10      <none>          53/UDP,53/TCP,9153/TCP   4h8m   k8s-app=kube-dns
```

release.name: v0.5.5
release.body:
## What's Changed
* Allow fixed virtual MAC for DHCP VIPs by @valtzu in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/434
* Enable kube-vip to only respond to svc with kube-vip's lb class by @abhinavmpandey08 in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/435
* fix: --table flag should add vip_routingtable env var not vip_wireguard by @alexandrevilain in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/446
* Build-fixes by @cprivitere in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/440
* This adds the initial code for egress (SNAT). by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/445
* Add random MAC address generation for DHCP by @daper in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/449
* Adds stability and warnings to egress by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/456
* Adds ports and namespaces by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/459

## New Contributors
* @valtzu made their first contribution in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/434
* @alexandrevilain made their first contribution in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/446
* @daper made their first contribution in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/449

pull_request.body:
Adds annotation watching for specific destination ports:

```

issue.title: Log flooded with "\"\" is not an Ethernet MAC address"
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

I just deployed `kube-vip` as a deamonset using this command

```
export INTERFACE=lo

kube-vip manifest daemonset \        
    --interface $INTERFACE \
    --address $VIP \
    --inCluster \
    --taint \
    --controlplane \
    --services \
    --arp \
    --leaderElection > daemonset.yaml
```

I aslo added the load-balancing environment variable.
```
        - name : lb_enable
          value: "true"
```

HA control plane is working correctly, and I can interact with the AP I server using the VIP.

However, leader pod's log is flooded with this warning/error message

```
 time="2022-10-04T06:04:38Z" level=warning msg="\"\" is not an Ethernet MAC address"
...

```



**Expected behavior**
Log is not flooded

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: ubuntu 22.04
 - Kubernetes Version: v1.24.4+k3s1
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.0

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
    app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
        app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/master
                operator: Exists
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/control-plane
                operator: Exists
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: vip_arp
          value: "true"
        - name: port
          value: "6443"
        - name: vip_interface
          value: <INTERFACE>
        - name: vip_cidr
          value: "32"
        - name: cp_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: cp_namespace
          value: kube-system
        - name : lb_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_ddns
          value: "false"
        - name: svc_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_leaderelection
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_leaseduration
          value: "5"
        - name: vip_renewdeadline
          value: "3"
        - name: vip_retryperiod
          value: "1"
        - name: address
          value: <VIP>
        - name: prometheus_server
          value: :2112
        image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.0
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
      hostNetwork: true
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
      tolerations:
      - effect: NoSchedule
        operator: Exists
      - effect: NoExecute
        operator: Exists

issue.title: Multi cluster loadbalancing
issue.body:
Hi,

i'm looking for an on premise solution for managing services of type load balancer in multiple kubernetes cluster. This is currently not supported and is maybe out of scope of this project. I recognized that this is possible by configuring kube-vip to use wireguard.

Would it be an acceptable feature if the kube-vip-cloud-provider could create services in an upstream cluster and mapping node ports of downstream cluster nodes to the upstream cluster service ?

Are there big disadvantages compared to the wireguard solution with kube-vip?

Or should it be a separate provider for that because the logic would be completely decoupled from the current kube-vip-cloud-provider implementation? 

I put already some time into an attempt to implement it in general. You can take a look on it at my [fork](https://github.com/soer3n/kube-vip-cloud-provider/tree/upstream_lb). I've tested it successfully with an ingress-nginx-controller but not with tls enabled until now. If it is acceptable for you i would like to open a pull request.

There are some limitations until now. Endpoints for Upstream Services are limited to one subset and sessionAffinity is hardcoded. I've added an example configuration to [examples directory](https://github.com/soer3n/kube-vip-cloud-provider/blob/upstream_lb/example/multi-cluster-example.yaml).

comment.body: Yeah, I'd love to chat about what your plans are!

pull_request.title: Update home page
pull_request.body:
## Description

Update the landing page's services to be representative of our current direction/service set. This includes:

- stop mentioning OSIE.
- add a note about `tink-controller`.
- add Rufio.
- stop mentioning Postgres.
- redirect new starts to the sandbox repository.

With respect to removing Postgres docs, I was split. We haven't implemented this yet but we have agreed its the direction we're taking. The Sandbox does still reference it and I felt that's OK until we get the sandbox functional with the Kubernetes back-end and begin stripping Postgres out. Updating this to no longer mention Postgres is going to steer people towrad Kubernetes.

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
externalTrafficPolicy: Local does not work. kube-vip does not detect endpoint changes in table mode (or at all?)

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1.Apply service + single-pod deployment manifest with affinity to single node (i.e. test-lab-worker02 in my case)
2. Change deployment pod affinity to another node (i.e. test-lab-worker03 in my case)
3. See no changes for loadbalancer address announcement

**Expected behavior**
kube-vip must remove the loadbalancer ip address announcement  from the node with no local pods and add it to another node

**Screenshots**
Deployment manifest
```
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: nginx
  labels:
    app: nginx
spec:
  ports:
  - port: 80
    protocol: TCP
    name: http
  selector:
    app: nginx
  externalTrafficPolicy: Local
  type: LoadBalancer
  loadBalancerIP: 192.168.164.64
---
kind: Deployment
apiVersion: apps/v1
metadata:
  name: nginx
  labels:
    app: nginx
spec:
  replicas: 1
  strategy:
    type: RollingUpdate
    rollingUpdate:
      maxSurge: 0
      maxUnavailable: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: nginx
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: nginx
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: kubernetes.io/hostname
                operator: In
                values:
                - test-lab-worker02
      containers:
      - image: nginx:1.21.5
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        name: nginx
        ports:
        - containerPort: 80
          protocol: TCP
```

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Ubuntu 1804
 - Kubernetes Version: v.1.20.15
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.0

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
---

  name: kube-vip

apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1

- kind: ServiceAccount
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
---

apiVersion: apps/v1

metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
    app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
        app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
    spec:
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        - --log=5

        - --services

issue.title: Question: multiple pods on different node - using the same egress IP?
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Is it possible to configure egress in a way that a deployment having multiple PODs on different nodes using the same egress VIP for outgoing traffic?

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Cluster with 10 nodes where three have a secondary NIC for egress traffic.
Configure kube-vip with a single VIP to be running on the three egress nodes.
Deploy a deployment with 10 pods - one on each node.
Configure kube-vip for this deployment to do egress over a single VIP.

**Expected behavior**
If a POD is hosted on node1 and egress VIP is on node 4 (secondary 5,6) - the egress traffic POD on node1 should go out via node 4 with the VIP specified in kube-vip.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: CentOS 7.9
 - Kubernetes Version: 1.22
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.5

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  annotations:
    deprecated.daemonset.template.generation: "4"
    meta.helm.sh/release-name: kube-vip
    meta.helm.sh/release-namespace: kube-vip
  creationTimestamp: "2022-10-12T14:28:41Z"
  generation: 4
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/managed-by: Helm
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-vip
  resourceVersion: "29852231"
  uid: ab939ff7-7cf5-4742-9d70-d939d84b6b34
spec:
  revisionHistoryLimit: 10
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/instance: kube-vip
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/instance: kube-vip
        app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: is_edge
                operator: In
                values:
                - "true"
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: vip_address
          value: 10.141.48.13
        - name: cp_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: lb_enable
          value: "false"
        - name: lb_port
          value: "6443"
        - name: svc_election
          value: "true"
        - name: svc_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_arp
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_cidr
          value: "32"
        - name: vip_interface
          value: eth1
        - name: vip_leaderelection
          value: "false"
        image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip-iptables:v0.5.5
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
        terminationMessagePath: /dev/termination-log
        terminationMessagePolicy: File
      dnsPolicy: ClusterFirst
      hostNetwork: true
      restartPolicy: Always
      schedulerName: default-scheduler
      securityContext: {}
      serviceAccount: kube-vip
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
      terminationGracePeriodSeconds: 30
      tolerations:
      - effect: NoSchedule
        key: node-role.kubernetes.io/control-plane
        operator: Exists
  updateStrategy:
    rollingUpdate:
      maxSurge: 0
      maxUnavailable: 1
    type: RollingUpdate

```

comment.body:
So technically it might be possible in the future however that would probably require routing traffic from a pod to an egress gateway, meaning it doesn't matter where the pod is currently running traffic is always sent to "somewhere", where it is then modified and sent on to it's final destination.

Today the re-write is done in-kernel and therefore everything has to happen on the node where a chosen pod is running. So that's why service election is required and external policy local.

issue.title: externalTrafficPolicy Local not working as expected
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Creating a service with `externalTrafficPolicy: Local` never gets advertised by kube-vip after receiving a loadbalancerIP from kube-vip-cloud-provider.

Logs complain that no local pods were found, even though they exist.

If I create the service with `externalTrafficPolicy: Cluster` it gets an IP, and if I edit/update the service and set `externalTrafficPolicy: Local` I get Local behavior as expected.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Deploy kube-vip + kube-vip-cloud-provider
  - ARP mode, see manifest below
2. Configure cidr/range for kvcp
3. Deploy a service with `externalTrafficPolicy: Local`
4. ExternalIP stuck in pending

**Expected behavior**
I expected kube-vip to advertise the IP.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Ubuntu 22.04
 - Kubernetes Version: k3s 1.23.9
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.0

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```yaml
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  revisionHistoryLimit: 10
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        name: kube-vip-ds
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/control-plane
                operator: Exists
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: cp_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: svc_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: address
          value: 192.168.60.100
        - name: port
          value: "6443"
        - name: vip_ddns
          value: "false"
        - name: prometheus_server
          value: :2112
        - name: vip_arp
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_interface
          value: eth0
        - name: vip_leaderelection
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_leaseduration
          value: "5"
        - name: vip_renewdeadline
          value: "3"
        - name: vip_retryperiod
          value: "1"
        - name: svc_election
          value: "true"
        image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.0
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
      dnsPolicy: ClusterFirst
      hostNetwork: true
      restartPolicy: Always
      schedulerName: default-scheduler
      securityContext: {}
      serviceAccount: kube-vip
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
      terminationGracePeriodSeconds: 30
      tolerations:
      - effect: NoSchedule
        operator: Exists
      - effect: NoExecute
        operator: Exists
  updateStrategy:
    rollingUpdate:
      maxSurge: 0
      maxUnavailable: 1
    type: RollingUpdate
status:
  currentNumberScheduled: 3
  desiredNumberScheduled: 3
  numberAvailable: 3
  numberMisscheduled: 0
  numberReady: 3
  observedGeneration: 2
  updatedNumberScheduled: 3
```

**Additional context**

Output from `kubectl get pod,svc -A -owide`:
```

release.name: v0.5.5
release.body:
## What's Changed
* Allow fixed virtual MAC for DHCP VIPs by @valtzu in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/434
* Enable kube-vip to only respond to svc with kube-vip's lb class by @abhinavmpandey08 in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/435
* fix: --table flag should add vip_routingtable env var not vip_wireguard by @alexandrevilain in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/446
* Build-fixes by @cprivitere in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/440
* This adds the initial code for egress (SNAT). by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/445
* Add random MAC address generation for DHCP by @daper in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/449
* Adds stability and warnings to egress by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/456
* Adds ports and namespaces by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/459

## New Contributors
* @valtzu made their first contribution in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/434
* @alexandrevilain made their first contribution in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/446
* @daper made their first contribution in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/449

issue.title: Log flooded with "\"\" is not an Ethernet MAC address"
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

I just deployed `kube-vip` as a deamonset using this command

```
export INTERFACE=lo

kube-vip manifest daemonset \        
    --interface $INTERFACE \
    --address $VIP \
    --inCluster \
    --taint \
    --controlplane \
    --services \
    --arp \
    --leaderElection > daemonset.yaml
```

I aslo added the load-balancing environment variable.
```
        - name : lb_enable
          value: "true"
```

HA control plane is working correctly, and I can interact with the AP I server using the VIP.

However, leader pod's log is flooded with this warning/error message

```
 time="2022-10-04T06:04:38Z" level=warning msg="\"\" is not an Ethernet MAC address"
...

```



**Expected behavior**
Log is not flooded

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: ubuntu 22.04
 - Kubernetes Version: v1.24.4+k3s1
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.0

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
    app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
        app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/master
                operator: Exists
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/control-plane
                operator: Exists
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: vip_arp
          value: "true"
        - name: port
          value: "6443"
        - name: vip_interface
          value: <INTERFACE>
        - name: vip_cidr
          value: "32"
        - name: cp_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: cp_namespace
          value: kube-system
        - name : lb_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_ddns
          value: "false"
        - name: svc_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_leaderelection
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_leaseduration
          value: "5"
        - name: vip_renewdeadline
          value: "3"
        - name: vip_retryperiod
          value: "1"
        - name: address
          value: <VIP>
        - name: prometheus_server
          value: :2112
        image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.0
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
      hostNetwork: true
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
      tolerations:
      - effect: NoSchedule
        operator: Exists
      - effect: NoExecute
        operator: Exists
  updateStrategy: {}
status:
  currentNumberScheduled: 0
  desiredNumberScheduled: 0
  numberMisscheduled: 0
  numberReady: 0
```

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

issue.title: Multi cluster loadbalancing
issue.body:
Hi,

i'm looking for an on premise solution for managing services of type load balancer in multiple kubernetes cluster. This is currently not supported and is maybe out of scope of this project. I recognized that this is possible by configuring kube-vip to use wireguard.

Would it be an acceptable feature if the kube-vip-cloud-provider could create services in an upstream cluster and mapping node ports of downstream cluster nodes to the upstream cluster service ?

Are there big disadvantages compared to the wireguard solution with kube-vip?

Or should it be a separate provider for that because the logic would be completely decoupled from the current kube-vip-cloud-provider implementation? 

I put already some time into an attempt to implement it in general. You can take a look on it at my [fork](https://github.com/soer3n/kube-vip-cloud-provider/tree/upstream_lb). I've tested it successfully with an ingress-nginx-controller but not with tls enabled until now. If it is acceptable for you i would like to open a pull request.

There are some limitations until now. Endpoints for Upstream Services are limited to one subset and sessionAffinity is hardcoded. I've added an example configuration to [examples directory](https://github.com/soer3n/kube-vip-cloud-provider/blob/upstream_lb/example/multi-cluster-example.yaml).

comment.body: Yeah, I'd love to chat about what your plans are!

Update the landing page's services to be representative of our current direction/service set. This includes:

- redirect new starts to the sandbox repository.

Updating this to no longer mention Postgres is going to steer people towrad Kubernetes.

issue.title: [0.5.0] externalTrafficPolicy: Local does not work. kube-vip does not detect endpoint changes in table mode (or at all?)
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
externalTrafficPolicy: Local does not work. kube-vip does not detect endpoint changes in table mode (or at all?)

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1.Apply service + single-pod deployment manifest with affinity to single node (i.e. test-lab-worker02 in my case)
2. Change deployment pod affinity to another node (i.e. test-lab-worker03 in my case)
3. See no changes for loadbalancer address announcement

**Expected behavior**
kube-vip must remove the loadbalancer ip address announcement  from the node with no local pods and add it to another node

**Screenshots**
Deployment manifest
```
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: nginx
  labels:
    app: nginx
spec:
  ports:
  - port: 80
    protocol: TCP
    name: http
  selector:
    app: nginx
  externalTrafficPolicy: Local
  type: LoadBalancer
  loadBalancerIP: 192.168.164.64
---
kind: Deployment
apiVersion: apps/v1
metadata:
  name: nginx
  labels:
    app: nginx
spec:
  replicas: 1
  strategy:
    type: RollingUpdate
    rollingUpdate:
      maxSurge: 0
      maxUnavailable: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: nginx
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: nginx
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: kubernetes.io/hostname
                operator: In
                values:
                - test-lab-worker02
      containers:
      - image: nginx:1.21.5
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        name: nginx
        ports:
        - containerPort: 80
          protocol: TCP
```

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Ubuntu 1804
 - Kubernetes Version: v.1.20.15
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.0

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: ServiceAccount
metadata:
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
---
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
kind: ClusterRole
metadata:
  annotations:
    rbac.authorization.kubernetes.io/autoupdate: "true"
  name: system:kube-vip-role
rules:
  - apiGroups: [""]
    resources: ["services", "services/status", "nodes", "endpoints"]
    verbs: ["list","get","watch", "update"]
  - apiGroups: ["coordination.k8s.io"]
    resources: ["leases"]
    verbs: ["list", "get", "watch", "update", "create"]
---
kind: ClusterRoleBinding
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: system:kube-vip-binding
roleRef:
  apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
  kind: ClusterRole
  name: system:kube-vip-role
subjects:
- kind: ServiceAccount
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-system
---

apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
    app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
        app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
    spec:
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        - --log=5
        - --table
        - --services
        - --servicesElection
        - --serviceInterface=kube-dummy-if
        image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.0
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
      hostNetwork: true
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
```

issue.title: Question: multiple pods on different node - using the same egress IP?
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Is it possible to configure egress in a way that a deployment having multiple PODs on different nodes using the same egress VIP for outgoing traffic?

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

Cluster with 10 nodes where three have a secondary NIC for egress traffic.
Configure kube-vip with a single VIP to be running on the three egress nodes.
Deploy a deployment with 10 pods - one on each node.
Configure kube-vip for this deployment to do egress over a single VIP.

**Expected behavior**
If a POD is hosted on node1 and egress VIP is on node 4 (secondary 5,6) - the egress traffic POD on node1 should go out via node 4 with the VIP specified in kube-vip.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: CentOS 7.9
 - Kubernetes Version: 1.22
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.5

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  annotations:
    deprecated.daemonset.template.generation: "4"
    meta.helm.sh/release-name: kube-vip
    meta.helm.sh/release-namespace: kube-vip
  creationTimestamp: "2022-10-12T14:28:41Z"
  generation: 4
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/managed-by: Helm
  name: kube-vip
  namespace: kube-vip
  resourceVersion: "29852231"
  uid: ab939ff7-7cf5-4742-9d70-d939d84b6b34
spec:
  revisionHistoryLimit: 10
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/instance: kube-vip
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/instance: kube-vip
        app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: is_edge
                operator: In
                values:
                - "true"
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: vip_address
          value: 10.141.48.13
        - name: cp_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: lb_enable
          value: "false"
        - name: lb_port
          value: "6443"
        - name: svc_election
          value: "true"
        - name: svc_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_arp
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_cidr
          value: "32"
        - name: vip_interface
          value: eth1
        - name: vip_leaderelection
          value: "false"
        image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip-iptables:v0.5.5
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
        terminationMessagePath: /dev/termination-log
        terminationMessagePolicy: File
      dnsPolicy: ClusterFirst
      hostNetwork: true
      restartPolicy: Always
      schedulerName: default-scheduler
      securityContext: {}
      serviceAccount: kube-vip
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
      terminationGracePeriodSeconds: 30
      tolerations:
      - effect: NoSchedule
        key: node-role.kubernetes.io/control-plane
        operator: Exists
  updateStrategy:
    rollingUpdate:
      maxSurge: 0
      maxUnavailable: 1
    type: RollingUpdate

```

comment.body:
So technically it might be possible in the future however that would probably require routing traffic from a pod to an egress gateway, meaning it doesn't matter where the pod is currently running traffic is always sent to "somewhere", where it is then modified and sent on to it's final destination.

Today the re-write is done in-kernel and therefore everything has to happen on the node where a chosen pod is running. So that's why service election is required and external policy local.

issue.title: [0.5.0] externalTrafficPolicy: Local does not work. kube-vip does not detect endpoint changes in table mode (or at all?)
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
externalTrafficPolicy: Local does not work. kube-vip does not detect endpoint changes in table mode (or at all?)

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1.Apply service + single-pod deployment manifest with affinity to single node (i.e. test-lab-worker02 in my case)
2. Change deployment pod affinity to another node (i.e. test-lab-worker03 in my case)
3. See no changes for loadbalancer address announcement

**Expected behavior**
kube-vip must remove the loadbalancer ip address announcement  from the node with no local pods and add it to another node

**Screenshots**
Deployment manifest
```
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: nginx
  labels:
    app: nginx
spec:
  ports:
  - port: 80
    protocol: TCP
    name: http
  selector:
    app: nginx
  externalTrafficPolicy: Local
  type: LoadBalancer
  loadBalancerIP: 192.168.164.64
---
kind: Deployment
apiVersion: apps/v1
metadata:
  name: nginx
  labels:
    app: nginx
spec:
  replicas: 1
  strategy:
    type: RollingUpdate
    rollingUpdate:
      maxSurge: 0
      maxUnavailable: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: nginx
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: nginx
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: kubernetes.io/hostname
                operator: In
                values:
                - test-lab-worker02
      containers:
      - image: nginx:1.21.5
        imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
        name: nginx
        ports:
        - containerPort: 80
          protocol: TCP
```

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Ubuntu 1804
 - Kubernetes Version: v.1.20.15
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.0

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
---
apiVersion: v1

  namespace: kube-system

  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds

    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
        app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
    spec:
      containers:
      - args:

issue.title: externalTrafficPolicy Local not working as expected
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Creating a service with `externalTrafficPolicy: Local` never gets advertised by kube-vip after receiving a loadbalancerIP from kube-vip-cloud-provider.

Logs complain that no local pods were found, even though they exist.

If I create the service with `externalTrafficPolicy: Cluster` it gets an IP, and if I edit/update the service and set `externalTrafficPolicy: Local` I get Local behavior as expected.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Deploy kube-vip + kube-vip-cloud-provider
  - ARP mode, see manifest below
2. Configure cidr/range for kvcp
3. Deploy a service with `externalTrafficPolicy: Local`
4. ExternalIP stuck in pending

**Expected behavior**
I expected kube-vip to advertise the IP.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: Ubuntu 22.04
 - Kubernetes Version: k3s 1.23.9
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.0

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```yaml

metadata:
  name: kube-vip-ds

          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
      dnsPolicy: ClusterFirst

        operator: Exists

status:

release.name: v0.5.5
release.body:
## What's Changed
* Allow fixed virtual MAC for DHCP VIPs by @valtzu in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/434
* Enable kube-vip to only respond to svc with kube-vip's lb class by @abhinavmpandey08 in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/435
* fix: --table flag should add vip_routingtable env var not vip_wireguard by @alexandrevilain in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/446
* Build-fixes by @cprivitere in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/440
* This adds the initial code for egress (SNAT). by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/445
* Add random MAC address generation for DHCP by @daper in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/449
* Adds stability and warnings to egress by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/456
* Adds ports and namespaces by @thebsdbox in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/459

## New Contributors
* @valtzu made their first contribution in https://github.com/kube-vip/kube-vip/pull/434

issue.title: Log flooded with "\"\" is not an Ethernet MAC address"
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

I just deployed `kube-vip` as a deamonset using this command

```
export INTERFACE=lo

kube-vip manifest daemonset \        
    --interface $INTERFACE \
    --address $VIP \
    --inCluster \
    --taint \
    --controlplane \
    --services \
    --arp \
    --leaderElection > daemonset.yaml
```

I aslo added the load-balancing environment variable.
```
        - name : lb_enable
          value: "true"
```

HA control plane is working correctly, and I can interact with the AP I server using the VIP.

However, leader pod's log is flooded with this warning/error message

```
 time="2022-10-04T06:04:38Z" level=warning msg="\"\" is not an Ethernet MAC address"
...

```



**Expected behavior**
Log is not flooded

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS/Distro: ubuntu 22.04
 - Kubernetes Version: v1.24.4+k3s1
 - Kube-vip Version: 0.5.0

**`Kube-vip.yaml`:**
```
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: DaemonSet
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: null
  labels:
    app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
    app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
  name: kube-vip-ds
  namespace: kube-system
spec:
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
  template:
    metadata:
      creationTimestamp: null
      labels:
        app.kubernetes.io/name: kube-vip-ds
        app.kubernetes.io/version: v0.5.0
    spec:
      affinity:
        nodeAffinity:
          requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
            nodeSelectorTerms:
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/master
                operator: Exists
            - matchExpressions:
              - key: node-role.kubernetes.io/control-plane
                operator: Exists
      containers:
      - args:
        - manager
        env:
        - name: vip_arp
          value: "true"
        - name: port
          value: "6443"
        - name: vip_interface
          value: <INTERFACE>
        - name: vip_cidr
          value: "32"
        - name: cp_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: cp_namespace
          value: kube-system
        - name : lb_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_ddns
          value: "false"
        - name: svc_enable
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_leaderelection
          value: "true"
        - name: vip_leaseduration
          value: "5"
        - name: vip_renewdeadline
          value: "3"
        - name: vip_retryperiod
          value: "1"
        - name: address
          value: <VIP>
        - name: prometheus_server
          value: :2112
        image: ghcr.io/kube-vip/kube-vip:v0.5.0
        imagePullPolicy: Always
        name: kube-vip
        resources: {}
        securityContext:
          capabilities:
            add:
            - NET_ADMIN
            - NET_RAW
      hostNetwork: true
      serviceAccountName: kube-vip
      tolerations:
      - effect: NoSchedule
        operator: Exists
      - effect: NoExecute
        operator: Exists
  updateStrategy: {}
status:
  currentNumberScheduled: 0
  desiredNumberScheduled: 0
  numberMisscheduled: 0
  numberReady: 0
```

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

issue.title: Multi cluster loadbalancing
issue.body:
Hi,

i'm looking for an on premise solution for managing services of type load balancer in multiple kubernetes cluster. This is currently not supported and is maybe out of scope of this project. I recognized that this is possible by configuring kube-vip to use wireguard.

Would it be an acceptable feature if the kube-vip-cloud-provider could create services in an upstream cluster and mapping node ports of downstream cluster nodes to the upstream cluster service ?

Are there big disadvantages compared to the wireguard solution with kube-vip?

Or should it be a separate provider for that because the logic would be completely decoupled from the current kube-vip-cloud-provider implementation? 

I put already some time into an attempt to implement it in general. You can take a look on it at my [fork](https://github.com/soer3n/kube-vip-cloud-provider/tree/upstream_lb). I've tested it successfully with an ingress-nginx-controller but not with tls enabled until now. If it is acceptable for you i would like to open a pull request.

There are some limitations until now. Endpoints for Upstream Services are limited to one subset and sessionAffinity is hardcoded. I've added an example configuration to [examples directory](https://github.com/soer3n/kube-vip-cloud-provider/blob/upstream_lb/example/multi-cluster-example.yaml).

comment.body: Yeah, I'd love to chat about what your plans are!
